[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_struct()] [Ability manipulation] Does new_move_struct() properly validate that the abilities from the struct handle are valid Move abilities, or can malicious bytecode inject invalid ability combinations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_struct()] [Generic type parameter bounds] Can crafted bytecode manipulate the type_parameters field to create structs with invalid generic type parameter constraints that violate Move's type system? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_struct()] [Event flag spoofing] Does struct_is_event() rely solely on metadata, and can attackers inject fake event metadata to make non-event structs appear as events, potentially bypassing event indexing security checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [View function bypass] Can an attacker craft bytecode where function_is_view() incorrectly classifies a state-mutating function as a view function, allowing unauthorized state reads or bypassing transaction fee requirements? (High)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [Entry function spoofing] Does new_move_function() properly validate the is_entry flag, or can malicious bytecode mark private functions as entry points to bypass access control checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [Visibility confusion] Can crafted bytecode manipulate the visibility field during conversion to make private functions appear public in API responses, misleading clients about callable functions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [Parameter type confusion] Does new_move_function() validate that parameter signatures match the function's actual parameter types, or can type mismatches cause incorrect function call encoding? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [Return type validation] Can malicious bytecode provide invalid return type signatures that cause API consumers to incorrectly parse function results, leading to data corruption? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: new_move_function()] [Generic type constraint bypass] Does new_move_function() properly validate generic type parameters and their constraints, or can attackers craft functions with invalid type parameter bounds? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: find_entry_function()] [Entry point bypass] Can an attacker exploit the is_entry filter in find_entry_function() by crafting bytecode with multiple functions having the same name but different entry flags, causing ambiguous entry point resolution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: find_entry_function()] [Name collision] Does find_entry_function() handle duplicate function names correctly, or can malicious modules define multiple entry functions with identical names to cause confusion in API responses? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: find_function()] [Function shadowing] Can an attacker exploit find_function() to shadow legitimate functions by defining functions with duplicate names, causing the API to return incorrect function metadata? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: find_function()] [Name validation] Does find_function() validate function name format and length, or can extremely long or malformed function names cause performance degradation or string processing vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: metadata()] [Malicious metadata] Can an attacker inject crafted RuntimeModuleMetadataV1 that exploits get_metadata_from_compiled_code() to cause parsing errors, memory corruption, or expose sensitive validator information? (High)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: metadata()] [Metadata size attack] Does metadata() have size limits on the returned RuntimeModuleMetadataV1, or can attackers craft bytecode with enormous metadata payloads that cause memory exhaustion in API servers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: function_is_view()] [View determination bypass] Can malicious bytecode manipulate metadata to make determine_is_view() incorrectly classify mutating functions as view functions, allowing state changes without proper gas accounting? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: function_is_view()] [Metadata dependency] Does function_is_view() have a fallback when metadata is None, and can this be exploited to bypass view function restrictions in contracts without metadata? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: struct_is_event()] [Event metadata spoofing] Can an attacker inject fake event attributes in struct_attributes metadata to make non-event structs appear as events, bypassing event emission security checks or indexing logic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: struct_is_event()] [Attribute validation] Does struct_is_event() validate that event attributes come from trusted sources, or can any metadata with is_event() return true regardless of struct legitimacy? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: struct_is_event()] [Metadata absence handling] Can the None case in struct_is_event() be exploited where legitimate events without metadata are incorrectly classified as non-events, breaking event handling? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: struct_is_enum()] [Enum detection bypass] Can malicious bytecode craft StructFieldInformation::DeclaredVariants to make regular structs appear as enums, exploiting enum-specific handling paths in the Move VM? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: struct_is_enum()] [Variant count validation] Does struct_is_enum() validate the number and structure of declared variants, or can zero-variant or malformed variant definitions cause undefined behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: CompiledScript::find_entry_function()] [Main function spoofing] Can an attacker exploit the hardcoded 'main' check in find_entry_function() for CompiledScript to bypass script validation by naming regular functions 'main'? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: CompiledScript::find_function()] [Function name collision] Does the CompiledScript implementation properly distinguish between the implicit main function and other potential function definitions in script bytecode? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/types/src/bytecode.rs] [Function: CompiledScript::function_is_view()] [View function assumption] Can the hardcoded false return in function_is_view() for CompiledScript be exploited if scripts are ever allowed to have view semantics, breaking security assumptions? (Low)
